G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: a. G.L. c. 208, § 28 – Governing modifications of custody orders based on the best interests of the child and material changes in circumstances.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: h. G.L. c. 208, § 28A – Establishing mechanisms for modifying parenting schedules to protect children’s welfare.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as both parties and the minor children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: f. G.L. c. 208, § 31 – Establishing the presumption that custodial determinations must focus on the child’s holistic well-being and safety.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: b. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985) – Reaffirming the "best interests of the child" standard as paramount in custody-related matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and repeatedly characterizes the best interests of the children as the paramount concern. Although the case is focused on removal/relocation rather than initial custody alone, it reaffirms that all such custody-related determinations, including relocation, are governed by the best-interests standard. The opinion then applies that standard in detail to the facts of the case.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin…; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 737 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: c. Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 737 (1996) – Addressing substantial change in circumstances as a threshold to modify custody orders.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the modification question under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and states that a Probate Court judge may modify a prior custody judgment only upon finding “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties,” and that this is a prerequisite to then considering the children’s best interests. The court upholds the judge’s finding of such a material and substantial change based on the mother’s rehabilitation, before going on to evaluate whether the split-custody arrangement served the twins’ best interests. That directly addresses substantial change in circumstances as a threshold requirement to modify custody orders.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: d. Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243 (2000) – Recognizing the importance of stability and predictability in children’s living environments.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the specific words “stability” or “predictability,” but it clearly endorses looking beyond the moment to the child’s long‑term welfare and overall living situation. The court emphasizes that custody decisions must consider the child’s “probable future,” and it approves the trial judge’s focus on consistent structure, routines, and the quality of the caregiving environment—concepts that embody stability and predictability in a child’s living arrangements. Thus, it indirectly but legitimately supports the cited proposition.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’… ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child[ ] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403, quoting from Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939).”

Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 604 (.proposition: e. Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 604 (1976) – Holding that parental fitness, ability to supervise, and caregiving arrangements are critical factors in determining custodial arrangements.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 604 (.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on procedural fairness in custody proceedings, specifically the right to cross‑examine a guardian ad litem whose report the judge relies on. While it briefly reiterates that the governing principle in custody cases is the child’s best interests, it does not discuss or identify parental fitness, ability to supervise, or specific caregiving arrangements as critical or enumerated factors for determining custody. The holding is about evidentiary procedure, not substantive custody criteria, so the citation does not support the proposition as stated.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 604 (.relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ … In order to provide the judge with needed information about a child’s family life, G. L. c. 215, § 56A, … authorizes a probate judge to appoint a guardian ad litem to investigate the facts relating to the care and custody of the minor children….”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.proposition: g. Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012) – Reiterating that the primary consideration in custody determinations is the child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the custody analysis under the best-interests standard, citing prior precedent and describing it as the governing and ‘touchstone’ inquiry in custody matters. The court then applies that standard to decide primary physical custody of Jill, confirming that the child’s best interests are the primary consideration in custody determinations.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998).

Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 202, 205 (1992)
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: i. Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 202, 205 (1992) – Highlighting the court’s broad discretion in adapting parenting arrangements to evolving child welfare needs.
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case does emphasize the trial judge’s broad discretion in modifying child support orders and adjusting them for factors like extraordinary visitation costs and attribution of income. However, it does not concern parenting plans, custody schedules, or the ongoing adaptation of “parenting arrangements” to evolving child welfare needs; its focus is financial (support amounts, income attribution, and travel expenses). Using it to highlight broad discretion over parenting arrangements, rather than child support modification, stretches the holding beyond its context.
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The broad discretion historically accorded trial judges in actions to modify child support orders…amply permits the consideration and balancing of all relevant factors in the application of the principle of attribution of income… Given the importance which attaches to ‘both parents hav[ing] frequent and continuing association with their child’…extensive adjustment of a support order to accommodate extended long-distance visitation is generally warranted and in the child’s best interest.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 152 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: j. Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 152 (2015) – Emphasizing that modifications must prioritize the child’s best interest amidst changing family dynamics.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision, not a general modification case about changing family dynamics. While it clearly holds that when the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ conflicts with the children’s best interests, the children’s interests are paramount, it does not broadly frame this as a rule about all modifications amid changing family dynamics. Citing it for a generalized modification principle about ‘changing family dynamics’ somewhat mischaracterizes its more specific holding on removal and best-interest balancing.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: “Where the real advantage to the custodial parent is at odds with the best interests of the children, the children’s interests are paramount. … However, a finding that the proposed move presents a real advantage to the physical custodian does not necessarily mean that the move is in the best interests of the children. Here, the real advantage to the mother does not align with the children’s best interests or the interests of the father… ‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.’”
